Summary: An introduction to the history, geography, plants and animals, government, people, and culture of New Zealand.
1. New Zealand - Juvenile literature.

Welcome to New Zealand!
New Zealand is an island nation in the Southern Hemisphere.
It is about 1,000 miles (1,600 km) from its nearest neighbor!
Its isolated location and many islands make it home to unique plants and animals.
New Zealand's people are mainly descendants of European immigrants and the native Maori (MOUR-ee).
The immigrants and natives blended their traditions to create a rich cultural mix.
But, this threatens the survival of the native Maori culture.
Today, New Zealand's government is working to promote growth, while preserving history.
Together, New Zealanders are working to make their country a great place to live for all of its people.

img.alt: Four girls standing together, one holding a soccer ball.

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "Hello from New Zealand!"
OFFICIAL NAME: New Zealand
CAPITAL: Wellington
Area: 103,738 square miles (268,680 sq km)
Mountain Range: Southern Alps
Highest Point: Mount Cook 12,349 feet (3,764 m)
Major Rivers: Waikato and Clutha Rivers
Lakes: Taupo, Te Anau, Manpouri
Population: 3,908,037 (July 2002 est.)
Major Cities: Wellington, Auckland, Christchurch
Languages: English, Maori
Religions: Protestantism, Catholicism
Form: Parliamentary democracy
Head of State: British monarch represented by governor general
Head of Government: Prime minister
Legislature: Parliament
Nationhood: September 26, 1907
Agricultural Products: Meat, fish, dairy products, wood; wheat, fruits, vegetables; timber
Mining Products: Petroleum, coal, natural gas
Manufactured Products: Processed foods, wood products, textiles, machinery
Money: New Zealand dollar (1 New Zealand dollar = 100 cents)

img.alt: Map of New Zealand showing Wellington, the New Zealand flag and money.

p.sent: Shown are pictures depicting where Wellington is located, New Zealand's flag, and New Zealand’s money.
Polynesian peoples migrate to New Zealand
Abel Tasman discovers New Zealand
James Cook maps New Zealand
Maori and British sign the Treaty of Waitangi
Hone Heke leads uprising; Maori Wars begin
British defeat Maori
War resumes between British and Maori
Te Kooti Rikirangi retreats from war; Maori Wars end
New Zealand wins independence from Britain
Treaty of Rarotonga
The United States ends ANZUS Treaty
Polynesian people first came to New Zealand in about 1000.
The Maori are descendants of these early people.
Early Maori peoples were hunters and gatherers.
Later, they gained skills in agriculture and fishing.
The Maori led an isolated existence until Dutchman Abel Tasman arrived.
Tasman worked for the Dutch East India Company.
He was searching for a continent in the Southern Hemisphere.
Tasman discovered New Zealand in December 1642.
The Maori, however, defended their homeland.
Tasman could not come ashore.
In 1769, Captain James Cook sailed around New Zealand.
He became friends with the Maori.
Captain Cook's successful exploration and mapping
of the islands led other explorers there.

img.alt: Many warriors all rowing in a large boat.

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "The Maori were fierce warriors, and tribes often waged war on each other."
By the late 1700s, explorers from other European countries had come to New Zealand.
They set up colonies to trade natural resources, such as flax and wood, and to hunt whales and
seals.
New Zealand became successful and profitable.
For this reason, the British wanted to annex New Zealand.
British officials signed the Treaty of Waitangi (WHY-tahng-gee) with the Maori in 1840.
It made England's monarch the ruler of New Zealand.
The few Maori who signed the treaty did not represent all of their people.
The Maori believed the land belonged to all, not to individuals.
Many were upset that the British settlers were taking land for themselves.
In 1845, Maori chief Hone Heke led an uprising against the settlers.
This started the Maori Wars.
The British won in 1846.
But in 1860, war broke out again.
The fighting continued until 1872, when a new Maori chief, Te Kooti Rikirangi (TAY KOO-tee ree-kee-RAHNG-gee), retreated.
The Maori and their culture were in danger of
extinction.
The government had given away much of their land during the wars.
And, diseases introduced by the Europeans killed many people.

img.alt: Many Maori walking, carrying flags and a large banner that reads "honour the treaty".

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "Many Maori protest on Waitangi Day."
Meanwhile, New Zealand continued to grow
and prosper.
Thousands of European settlers had moved there.
In 1907, New Zealand became a self-governing country.

img.alt: Memorial with statues of people around a pilar, with a large angel on the top.

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "This memorial in Christchurch honors soldiers who lost their lives during World Wars I and II."
New Zealanders aided the British during the South African War and World War I.
Many soldiers lost their lives in battle.
During this time,
however, many New Zealanders developed a sense of pride in their country.
During World War II, New Zealand supplied food to Britain.
And once again, its soldiers fought bravely.
After the war, the United States, Australia, and New Zealand signed the ANZUS Treaty.
It formed an alliance between the countries to protect the South Pacific from future aggression.
Then, in 1985, New Zealand signed the Treaty of Rarotonga (rar-uh-TAHNG-guh).
It created the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone.
After this, New Zealand would not let nuclear-powered watercraft into its waters.
So in 1986, the United States ended the ANZUS Treaty.
Today, New Zealand's government continues to work to improve conditions for its people.
It's trying to repay the Maori for past injustices.
And, New Zealand is increasing its participation in the world market.
The country's people are working together to make New Zealand a great place to work and live for everyone.
New Zealand is an island nation in the Southern Hemisphere.
The country's land is made up of three large islands and many smaller islands.
New Zealand's nearest neighbor is Australia, located about 1,000 miles (1,600 km) away.
North Island has a dramatic landscape.
In the center of the island is an area of active volcanoes.
This area also has many lakes.
The largest is Lake Taupo.
North of the volcanoes are limestone caves.
They are called the Waitomo (why-TOH-moh)
Caves.
Farther north is a thermal region.
This area has geysers and hot springs.

img.alt: Lady Knox geyser.

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "This geyser, called Lady Knox, can be found on Waiotapu Thermal Reserve. Vistors come to watch it erupt."

img.alt: The location of New Zealand both on the Earth and realtive to Australia along with A more detailed map of New Zealand, showing the features described in the text.

p.sent: Three maps are shown. The first shows New Zealand’s location on a map of the Earth. The second shows its location southeast of Australia. The third shows a detailed map of New Zealand.
Cook Strait separates North Island and South Island.
South Island is New Zealand's largest island.
New Zealanders call it the Mainland.
The Southern Alps run along this island's west coast.
They contain Mount Cook, the nation's highest peak.
East of the Southern Alps is a wide plain.
It is called Canterbury Plains.
South of the mountains and plains, fjords lead into Foveaux (FOH-voh) Strait.
Across Foveaux Strait is Stewart Island.
It is hilly and wooded.
The island has inlets, ports, and bays.
The island's Halfmoon Bay is the southernmost place in New Zealand where people live.
New Zealand's rivers are short and swift.
They are not good for navigation, but they do generate much of New Zealand's energy.
The Waikato River is the longest at 264 miles (425 km) long.
Winds from the sea bring much rain to the country, but most falls west of the mountains.
Because of New Zealand's location, its climate is mild year-round.

img.alt: Map showing the average yearly rainfall in different parts of New Zealand and differences in temperature in different parts of New Zealand during the summer and winter.

p.sent: Three maps of New Zealand are shown.
The first shows average yearly rainfall in different parts of New Zealand.
The second and third maps show differences in temperature in different parts of New Zealand during the summer and winter.
New Zealand's varied landscape makes it home to many plants and animals.
Because of the country's geographic isolation, some are found nowhere else on Earth.
Forests cover about one-fourth of New Zealand's land.
Beech is the most common tree.
Rimu is a hardwood tree that grows very slowly.
Rimu trees can live to be hundreds of years old.

img.alt: The forest.

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "This forest has been preserved, which means people can't destroy the area."
Below the forests, in the lower elevations, grasses grow.
Lizards, frogs, and bats are New Zealand's only indigenous animals.
Other animals, such as cows, were brought to New Zealand from other countries.
And, while New Zealand is home to many kinds of animals, no snakes live there at all!
More than 250 species of birds live in New Zealand, including the kiwi and the weka.
The kiwi is a small gray-brown bird.
Its feathers are soft and hairlike.
It sleeps in burrows dug into the ground.

img.alt: Kiwi partially hidden behind a plant.

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "Kiwis like to eat worms, and they can sleep for up to 20 hours a day."
Most New Zealanders are of European descent.
They are known as pakeha (PAH-kuh-hah).
The second-largest ethnic group is the Maori.
There are also Asians, Pacific Islanders, and Indians in New Zealand.
English and Maori are New Zealand's official languages.
The country does not have an official religion.
Most New Zealanders are Anglican, Presbyterian, or Catholic.
Almost all New Zealanders live in cities.
Most own a family home.
These houses often have attached gardens.
Opposite page: These Maori women are celebrating their culture through native clothing and dance.

img.alt: Maori women celebrating their culture through native clothing and dance.

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "These Maori women are celebrating their culture through native clothing and dance."
New Zealand's many immigrant groups have contributed to its food.
The traditional dish is roast lamb.
Many New Zealanders enjoy a traditional breakfast of eggs, meats, and potatoes before heading to work or school.
Children must attend school from age six to age 15.
Almost every New Zealander can read and write.
Six years of primary school are followed by secondary school.
After completing secondary school, students can attend one of New Zealand's seven universities.

img.alt: Young students sitting around a table with their teacher.

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "Students in New Zealand learn about their country's history."

img.alt: New Zealand Pavlova recipie.

p.sent:
This dish is often served at parties and during holidays. 3 egg whites
1 cup white sugar
2 tablespoons water
3 teaspoons cornstarch
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
1 teaspoon distilled white vinegar
Preheat oven to 275°F (135°C).
Line a cookie sheet with foil and spray on a little cooking spray.
In a large mixing bowl, beat egg whites until foamy.
Gradually add sugar.
Continue to beat until stiff peaks form.
Beat in water, cornstarch, vanilla, and vinegar.
Pour entire mixture onto the center of the cookie sheet.
Bake for 45 minutes.
Turn oven off and leave Pavlova in the oven until cold.
Turn upside down onto plate and top with fresh fruit and whipped cream.
AN IMPORTANT NOTE TO THE CHEF: Always have an adult help with the preparation of cooking of food.
Never use kitchen utensils or appliances without adult permission and supervision.

p.sent: English

Children
Visitor
Most New Zealanders work in the service industry.
Some work in community and social service jobs.
Others work in banking and finance, insurance, and real estate.
Hotel and restaurant workers contribute to the nation's growing tourist industry.
New Zealanders who work in manufacturing make domestic products.
These products include processed foods, cars, furniture, and electronics.
New Zealand has to import the raw materials it needs to make products.
So, manufacturing is expensive.
New Zealanders mine petroleum and coal.
Most of these resources are used domestically to produce energy.
Some are sent to other countries.
Hydropower and geothermal energy

img.alt: Large, beautiful building in the distance with white and purple flowers in front of it.

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "This museum and restaurant used to be New Zealand's government bathhouse."
provide most of New Zealand's electricity.
Gold and iron are also important mining products.
Agriculture employs the least amount of New Zealanders.
But, its products are the country's chief exports.
Farmers raise sheep for butter, meat, wool, and cheese.
They also grow wheat, apples, corn, and potatoes.
New Zealand is the world's largest producer of kiwifruit and lamb.
It is the world's second-largest producer of wool.
Loggers harvest many trees.
This activity has depleted much of New Zealand's native forests.
Now, imported trees make up most of the harvest.
New Zealanders who work in this industry manufacture pulp, paper, timber, and other wood products.

img.alt: This shepherd is guarding his sheep with his motorcycle and sheepdogs!

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "This shepherd is guarding his sheep with his motorcycle and sheepdogs!"

img.alt: Two farmers pitching hay.

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "Farmers in New Zealand working in the fields."
Auckland is New Zealand's largest city.
About 1 million people live there.
The city was built on North Island in 1840.
It was New Zealand's capital until 1865.
Auckland is on an isthmus between the Tasman Sea and the Pacific Ocean.
This makes it a major port and center of trade and shipping.
Its manufactured goods include clothing, cars, and processed foods.

img.alt: A view of Wellington by the sea.

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "A view of Wellington from Mount Victoria."
Wellington became the nation's capital in 1865.
It is on North Island, too.
The
nation's parliament and government offices are there.
Mount Victoria is the city's center.
Wellington is New Zealand's transportation and communication hub.
Many goods are shipped through its harbor.
The city's manufactured goods include clothing, transportation parts, chemicals, and processed foods.
Christchurch is another large city in New Zealand.
It was built on South Island in 1850.
It is one of the nation's centers of education.
Products from the city include clothing, carpet, rubber, and wood.

img.alt: Christchurch Cathedral.

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "Christchurch Cathedral."
The country has more than 57,000 miles (92,000 km) of roads.
Most of New Zealand's families own a car.
This is the most popular way to get around.
New Zealanders can travel in other ways, too.
Bus service links all of the country's major cities and towns.
These cities are also linked by rail.
The nation's leading international airport is in Auckland.
There are also international airports in Wellington and Christchurch.
Air New Zealand is the country's biggest air carrier.
Auckland and Wellington have busy shipping ports.
Most of the nation's imports and exports travel through these two waterways.
Opposite page: Cruise ships, as well as many other boats, can be found docked at Wellington's harbor.

img.alt: Cruise ship docked at Wellington's harbor.

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "Cruise ships, as well as many other boats, can be found docked at Wellington’s harbor."
New Zealand is a parliamentary democracy.
Great Britain's monarch is also New Zealand's sovereign.
The monarch appoints a governor general to represent the monarchy.
The governor general then serves as New Zealand's head of state.
New Zealand's legislature is a one-house parliament.
It is called the House of Representatives.
There are 120 representatives elected to serve three-year terms.
Maori representatives must hold at least five of these seats.
The head of New Zealand's government is the prime minister.
He or she is the leader of the majority party in parliament.
The prime minister recommends a cabinet, which is appointed by the governor general.
The Privy Council is the nation's highest court.
It is located in the United Kingdom.
There is also a High Court.
Citizens in each of the nation's 14 regions elect a representative council.
Each region is divided into cities.
Citizens in each city elect a council, which is headed by a mayor.

img.alt: New Zealand government buildings.

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "New Zealand's government works to create equality among its people."
New Zealanders celebrate many holidays.
Some holidays, such as Christmas Day or Labor Day, are similar to those celebrated in other countries.
But, New Zealanders also have holidays that are unique to their culture.
For example, February 6 is Waitangi Day.
This holiday celebrates the signing of the Treaty of Waitangi.
But, many Maori do not celebrate this holiday.
They are protesting the damage this treaty has done to their culture.
New Zealanders also honor their brave soldiers.
During World War I, New Zealand and Australia formed the Australian and New Zealand Army Corps (ANZAC).
Today, ANZAC Day is celebrated on April 25.
It commemorates all the soldiers who died in war.
It also honors all of the men and women who have served in war.

img.alt: A policeman playing bagpipes

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "Celebrating on Waitangi Day."
New Zealanders have many ways to relax.
One of the most popular is participating in or watching sporting events.
Rugby is the nation's most popular sport.
The All Blacks is New Zealand's national team.
Many of the team's matches are played in Auckland's Eden Park.

img.alt: A rugby team, wearing maroon and gold shirts.

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "Rugby is a popular sport for all the ages to watch and play."
New Zealand also has many national parks, and each offers unique recreation options.
Tongariro National Park has three active volcanoes.
They are Tongariro, Ngauruhoe, and Ruapehu.
Other parks offer skiing, hiking, and mountain climbing.
New Zealand is a beautiful country with many natural resources.
Its diverse population has come together to create a rich culture.
New Zealanders are working together to preserve this culture and to keep New Zealand a great place to visit and live.

img.alt: Two campers sitting on the ground, looking at Mount Ngauruhoe in the distance.

p.sent: Picture shown with the caption, "These campers are enjoying a view of Mount Ngauruhoe."
aggression - displaying forceful or hostile actions.
alliance - people, groups, or nations joined together for a common cause.
annex - to take land and add it to a nation.
commemorate - to honor the memory of.
culture - the customs, arts, and tools of a nation or people at a certain time.
deplete - to empty of a main substance.
descendant - a person who comes from a particular ancestor or group of ancestors.
diverse - composed of several distinct pieces or qualities.
Dutch East India Company - a company formed to expand Dutch trade and maintain close contact between the Dutch government and its colonies.
ethnic - of or having to do with a group of people who have the same race, nationality, or culture.
fjord - a long, narrow, and deep inlet of a sea between two steep slopes.
flax - a fiber from the stem of a plant.
geothermal - using the heat of the earth's interior.
geyser - a natural hot spring from which steam and hot water shoot into the air.
hemisphere - one half of Earth.
hydropower - electricity produced by water-powered generators.
immigration - entry into another country to live.
A person who immigrates is called an immigrant.
indigenous - having originated in a particular region or environment.
isolated - to be separated from something.
isthmus - a narrow strip of land connecting two larger land areas.
nuclear - of or relating to the energy created when atoms are divided or combined.
parliament - the highest lawmaking body of some governments.
parliamentary democracy - a form of government in which the decisions of the nation are made by the people through the elected parliament.
petroleum - a thick, yellowish black oil. It is used to make gasoline.
prime minister - the highest-ranked member of some governments.
pulp - a soft and moist mass of wood fibers used in making paper.
rugby - a form of football played with an oval ball by two, 15-person teams.
sovereign - the supreme ruler of a monarchy, such as a king or queen.
unique - being the only one of its kind.
